ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned about analyzing music, looking at architecture in new ways, and comparing the two.

Coming into this course, I had previous knowledge of jazz music and no knowledge of architecture. Through the course, I learned about more abstract methods of discussion jazz and architecture, the broad history of both fields, and more modern and avantgarde approaches. I gained skills in reading abstract and sometimes confusing texts and insights into the formal elements that connect the two fields.
Become more familiar with the discourses of music and architecture, develop tools for interdisciplinary analysis
Overview of jazz history, the different genres of jazz and how they came to be; overview of architectural theory and different close analyses of specific projects

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think it was a strength that the class size was so small, but it could be improved with better instructions on how to write in the abstract manner necessary.

Strengths: deep dive into complex ideas. very interesting for people interested in aesthetics with sound and space. Professor Veal is a great discussioner

Weaknesses: Sometimes it seems difficult to understand contemporary architecture without prior experience in traditional architecture but still is exciting to be exposed to new methodologies in the field.

Strengths: interesting material - as someone who has never learned about jazz or architecture, it was nice to get an overview of both and how they interact  

Weaknesses: by the end of the course I was unsure whether or not I completely understood the connection between jazz and architecture, concepts are very difficult to articulate

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The class discussions succeeded because I was actively engaged, participating, and therefore learning.

We didn't use any functions besides zoom itself (the class was only 5 students so breakout rooms would be too small), understanding some music concepts was difficult because of timing differences in zoom as well as not being able to gather around a piano

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes I would recommend this course to another student because it is a course I would not usually take, but was very beneficial to my perspective on things.

Definitely would recommend as a seminar for those interested in jazz or architecture, as it expands your thinking in these fields. Contemporary architecture and free jazz are not often taught and sometimes complicated to understand, but the seminar engages both from a unique perspective

Hmm. Yes and no. If you are the type of student who can think really abstractly (or wants to learn how) then this is a good class for you. Jazz and architecture are two very different topics and, while they do have a lot of overlap, it can be really difficult to wrap your head around at times. The professor understands that this is difficult for students and the course moves in a way that makes the dots easy to connect.
